citation.article-title: Clostridium quinii sp. nov., a new saccharolytic anaerobic bacterium isolated from granular sludge.

p.s: Description of Clostridium quinii sp. nov.
Clostridium quinii (qui'ni.i. M.L. gen. n. quinii of Quin; named after J. I. Quin, a South African microbiologist who first described a large ovoid bacterium)
Morphological cycle present; rods straight with pointed ends; first motil with peritrichous flagella (2.5-5 x 1 μm), later becoming immotile.
Cells contain glycogen-like inclusions (5-10 x 3-6 μm) during swelling phase.
Long endospores straight to slightly curved.
Colonies on agar translucent.
Unpigmented.
Strictly anaerobic.
Tmin..: 15°C, Topt.: 40-45°C, Tmax.: 45-50°C pH range for growth 6.2-10.5; pH optimum around 7.4.
No growth in media without carbohydrates.
Chemo-organotroph.

Utilizes a large variety of carbohydrates as carbon and energy sources, including glucose, fructose, xylose, galactose, mannose, saccharose, cellobiose, maltose, raffinose, gentiobiose, turanose, mannitol, arbutine and salicine.

Compounds not utilized as carbon and energy sources include cellulose, starch, ribose, rhamnose, lactose, inositol, xylitol, sorbitol, dulcitol, glycerol, lactate, citrate, tartrate, fumarate, benzoate, pyruvate, hexanol and acetone.
Indole absent.
Esculin hydrolyzed, but not gelatin.
Nitrate and sulphate not serving as final electron acceptors.
Lecithinase and urease absent.
Vitamins not required although biotin stimulates growth.
Ammonium salts used exclusively as nitrogen sources.
Major fermentation products are formate, acetate, lactate, ethanol and hydrogen with butyrate in minor amounts.
Metabolism not modified by hydrogen or carbon monoxide.
G + C-content of type strain DNA 28.0 mol% (Tm).
Habitat: Anaerobic sludge.
Type strain: Clostridium quinii BS1 is designated as the type strain and has been deposited in the German Collection of Microorganisms (Braunschweig) under the number DSM 6736.
